**[Context Text]**
Panel Scan Diagram
The diagram below describes each crew member’s area of responsibility and scan flow pattern for each panel when the airplane is not moving under its own power.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram illustrates the panel scan flow and crew member responsibilities.
- The `Captain` is responsible for areas indicated by a shaded square.
- The `First Officer` is responsible for areas indicated by an unshaded circle.

The scan flow is as follows:
Step [1]: The scan begins at the First Officer's side panels located to the far left and far right of the cockpit.
Step [2]: The flow then moves to the overhead panel, covering the Captain's responsibility on the left side and the First Officer's responsibility on the right side.
Step [3]: Next, the scan proceeds to the glareshield panel, which is the First Officer's responsibility across both the left and right sections.
Step [4]: The flow continues to the forward instrument panel, encompassing the Captain's responsibility on the left and the First Officer's responsibility on the right.
Step [5]: The scan moves downwards from the center instrument panel, which is the First Officer's responsibility, to the center console.
Step [6]: The scan includes the Throttle Quadrant on the center console, which is the First Officer's responsibility.
Step [7]: The flow covers the Communication Management Unit (CMU) / radio tuning panel (RTP) area within the center console, which is the First Officer's responsibility.
Step [8]: The scan moves to the lower center console, covering the Captain's responsibility on the left side and the First Officer's responsibility on the right side.
Step [9]: Finally, the scan includes the Control Display Units (CDUs) / FMS panels in the center console, which are the First Officer's responsibility.

**[Context Text]**
Pilot Flying/Taxiing and Pilot Not Flying/Not Taxiing Areas of Responsibility
The diagram below describes each crew member's area of responsibility for each panel when the airplane is moving under its own power.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram illustrates areas of responsibility in the Boeing B737 cockpit:

**Pilot Flying/Taxiing (PF) area of responsibility (light gray shading):**
*   The Mode Control Panel (MCP) located on the glare shield.
*   The standby instruments located centrally on the main instrument panel.
*   The throttle quadrant, speed brake lever, and flaps lever on the aisle stand.
*   The left Control Display Unit (CDU) on the aisle stand.
*   The left Audio Control Panel (ACP) / Radio Tuning Panel (RMP) on the aisle stand.
*   The parking brake handle on the aisle stand.
*   The rudder trim controls on the aisle stand.
*   Central portions of the overhead panel, including some light switches and indicators.
*   The engine start panel on the aisle stand.

**Pilot Not Flying/Not Taxiing (PNF) area of responsibility (dark gray/black shading):**
*   The right Control Display Unit (CDU) on the aisle stand.
*   The right Audio Control Panel (ACP) / Radio Tuning Panel (RMP) on the aisle stand.
*   The center Radio Tuning Panel (RMP) on the aisle stand.
*   Various switches and panels on the aft and side portions of the overhead panel (e.g., APU panel, some lighting controls).

**Unshaded areas are the responsibility of the pilot seated on the respective side:**
*   The Captain's (left) main instrument panel, including the Primary Flight Display (PFD), Navigation Display (ND), and associated controls.
*   The First Officer's (right) main instrument panel, including the Primary Flight Display (PFD), Navigation Display (ND), and associated controls.
*   The landing gear lever on the Captain's side of the main instrument panel.
*   The stabilizer trim wheels on the aisle stand.
*   The Captain's and First Officer's side panels/consoles.
*   Most of the overhead panel, excluding the specific PF and PNF areas.
*   The circuit breaker panels on the aisle stand.

**[Context Text]** Engine Start Procedure **[Visual Analysis]** | CAPTAIN | FIRST OFFICER | |---|---| | Announce engine start sequence. | | | Normal starting sequence is 2, 1. | | | Call “STARTING ENGINE No. ___” | | | Position ENGINE START switch to GRD. | | | Verify increase in N2 RPM. | | | Acknowledge first officer’s report. | Verify increase in oil pressure by the time engine is stabilized at idle and call “OIL PRESSURE RISING” when observed. | | Position engine start lever to IDLE detent when:
• N1 rotation is observed and
• N2 RPM reaches 25% or (if 25% N2 is not achievable)
• at max motoring and a minimum of 20% N2.
Max motoring occurs when N2 acceleration is less than 1% in approximately 5 seconds. | | | Verify fuel flow and EGT indication | | | [Without automatic ignition]
At 56% N2 RPM check ENGINE START switch moves to OFF; if not, position start switch to OFF. | [Without automatic ignition]
Verify START VALVE OPEN alert extinguishes as the ENGINE START switch moves to OFF and report “STARTER CUTOUT.” | | [Automatic ignition]
At 56% N2 RPM check ENGINE START switch moves to AUTO; if not, position start switch to AUTO. | [Automatic ignition]
Verify START VALVE OPEN alert extinguishes as the ENGINE START switch moves to AUTO and report “STARTER CUTOUT.” | | Monitor N1, N2, EGT, fuel flow and oil pressure for normal indications as the engine accelerates and stabilizes at idle | Monitor N1, N2, EGT, fuel flow and oil pressure for normal indications as the engine accelerates and stabilizes at idle |

**[Context Text]** Takeoff Procedure **[Visual Analysis]** | PILOT FLYING | PILOT NOT FLYING | |---|---| | Advance thrust levers to approximately 40% N1. | | | Observe engine instruments stabilized and normal. | | | Push either TO/GA switch to advance the thrust levers to takeoff N1. | | | Verify mode annunciation. | Ensure thrust levers advance to takeoff N1. Observe mode annunciation.
Note: In cases of extreme headwind, the thrust levers may not advance to full N1. In this case, manually advance the thrust levers as required. | | Note: After takeoff thrust is set, the captain's hand must be on the thrust levers until V1. | | | Hold light forward pressure on the control column, maintain directional control. | Monitor engine instruments. Verify oil pressure is not in the amber band. | | Verify 80 knots. | Call “80 KNOTS.” | | | Verify that A/T annunciation changes to THR HLD by 84 knots | | Monitor airspeed, noting V1, and rotate smoothly at VR. | [Automatic V1 callout]
Confirm automatic V1 callout or call “V1”. | | | At VR call “ROTATE”. | | | Monitor flight instruments. | | When a positive rate of climb is indicated, call “GEAR UP” and continue rotation to takeoff pitch attitude. | Verify positive rate of climb. | | | Position landing gear lever UP. | | Check flight instrument indications. | |

**[Context Text]** After Takeoff Procedure **[Visual Analysis]** | PILOT FLYING | PILOT NOT FLYING | |---|---| | Maintain a minimum of V2 + 15 knots during initial climb. At light gross weight a higher speed (up to V2 + 25) may be selected, to synchronize F/D pitch command and avoid objectionable body attitude. | Monitor engine instruments and cross–check flight progress. | | Above 400 feet, call for appropriate roll mode, if required. Verify proper mode annunciation. | Select/verify roll mode. Verify proper mode annunciation. | | [Without auto T/O thrust reduction]
Above 1,000 feet, call for N1 and flaps up maneuvering speed. Verify flight and thrust mode annunciations. | [Without auto T/O thrust reduction]
Select N1 and set flaps up maneuvering speed. | | [Auto T/O thrust reduction]
Above 1,000 feet, call for flaps up maneuvering speed. Verify flight and thrust mode annunciations at thrust reduction altitude. | [Auto T/O thrust reduction]
Set flaps up maneuvering speed.
Verify climb thrust is set.
Verify proper mode annunciation. | | When above minimum altitude for autopilot engagement, engage A/P.
Verify flight mode annunciation. | Verify autopilot engaged. | | Retract flaps on takeoff flap retraction speed schedule. | Position FLAP lever as directed and monitor flaps and slats retraction. | | Call “AFTER TAKEOFF CHECKLIST” when flaps are up. | Position landing gear lever OFF, APU and engine start switches as required. Verify air conditioning and pressurization operating normally. Accomplish the AFTER TAKEOFF checklist. | | Above 3,000 feet AGL, engage VNAV or select normal climb speed and verify annunciation. | Verify proper mode annunciation. |

**[Context Text]**
CAUTION: To avoid the possibility of shoulder harness buckles snapping back and pulling or damaging circuit breakers, hold both straps before releasing and then allow straps to retract slowly to the stowed position.
*   “UP” – Flaps up maneuvering speed.
*   “1”, “5”, “10”, “15”, “25” – Number corresponding to flap maneuvering speed.
Note: Limit bank angle to 15 degrees until reaching V2 + 15.

**[Visual Analysis]**
| T/O FLAPS | SELECT FLAPS | AT: (for all weights) |
|---|---|---|
| 25 | 15 | V2 + 15 |
| 25 | 5 | “15” |
| 25 | 1 | “5” |
| 25 | UP | “1” |
| 15 | 5 | V2 + 15 |
| 15 | 1 | “5” |
| 15 | UP | “1” |
| 10 | 5 | V2 + 15 |
| 10 | 1 | “5” |
| 10 | UP | “1” |
| 5 | 1 | V2 + 15 |
| 5 | UP | “1” |
| 1 | UP | “1” |

**[Context Text]**
Climb and Cruise Procedure

**[Visual Analysis]**
| PILOT FLYING | PILOT NOT FLYING |
|---|---|
| | Position landing lights OFF passing through 10,000 feet. |
| Set altimeters to standard at transition altitude. | |
| Approaching selected FMC cruise altitude, verify level off and proper mode/N1 limit annunciation. | |
| | Position center tank fuel pump switches OFF when both pump LOW PRESSURE lights illuminate. |
| | During the last hour of cruise on all extended range (more than one hour from an adequate airport) flights, perform Fuel Crossfeed Valve check. |
| Set MCP altitude selector for descent. | Prior to top of descent, select and verify the planned arrival procedure on the FMC. |
| At top of descent point observe descent initiated and verify proper mode annunciation. | |

Note: If a center tank LOW PRESSURE light(s) illuminates during takeoff or initial climb, the center tank pump(s) may remain on until the climb attitude is reduced and the light(s) extinguishes or workload allows for the pump(s) to be positioned OFF.

Note: When established in a level attitude at cruise, if the center tank contains usable fuel and the center tank pump switches are off, the center tank pump switches should be positioned ON again. If the center tank contains more than 1000 lbs/453 kgs, the center tank pump switches must be positioned ON. Verify the LOW PRESSURE lights extinguish and position both switches OFF when both LOW PRESSURE lights illuminate.

**[Context Text]**
Note: If a center tank LOW PRESSURE light(s) illuminate(s) during descent, position the center tank fuel pump switch(es) to OFF.
Note: When established in a level attitude, if the center tank contains usable fuel and the center tank pump switches are off, the center tank pump switches should be positioned ON again. If the center tank contains more than 1000 lbs/453 kgs, the center tank pump switches must be positioned ON. Verify the LOW PRESSURE lights extinguish and position both switches OFF when both LOW PRESSURE lights illuminate.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The following table outlines the Descent and Approach Procedure, detailing tasks for the Pilot Flying and Pilot Not Flying:

| PILOT FLYING | PILOT NOT FLYING |
|:---|:---|
| | Position center tank fuel pump switches OFF when both pump LOW PRESSURE lights illuminate. |
| Check and set VREF and approach speeds as required. | |
| | Set anti-ice as required. |
| | Verify pressurization set for destination airport elevation and system operating normally. |
| Set AUTO BRAKE select switch to desired brake setting. | |
| Set and crosscheck altimeters at transition level. | |
| Set and crosscheck course selection and RADIO/BARO minimums as required for approach. | |
| Set and verify ADF and VHF NAV radios for approach. | |
| | Position fixed landing lights ON passing through 10,000 feet. |
| Call “DESCENT—APPROACH CHECKLIST.” | Accomplish the DESCENT—APPROACH checklist. |
| Call “FLAPS ____” according to flap speed schedule. | Position FLAP lever as directed and monitor flap and slat extension. |
| | Accomplish standard callouts. |
| Approaching selected FMC altitude verify level off and mode annunciation. | |

**[Context Text]** Landing Procedure **[Visual Analysis]** | PILOT FLYING | PILOT NOT FLYING | |---|---| | When on localizer intercept heading, verify ILS tuned and identified, LOC and G/S pointer displayed, arm APP mode and engage second autopilot | Set transponder mode selector to desired TCAS mode. | | Verify mode annunciation. | | | At localizer capture verify proper mode annunciation and set appropriate heading | Verify proper mode annunciation. | | At glide slope “alive”, call “GEAR DOWN”, “FLAPS 15.” Arm speed brake and check green light illuminated. Call “LANDING CHECKLIST DOWN TO FLAPS.” | [Without automatic ignition]
Position landing gear lever DN, FLAP lever to the 15 detent. Position engine start switches to CONT. Check RECALL. | | | [Automatic ignition]
Position landing gear lever DN, FLAP lever to the 15 detent. Check RECALL. | | | Accomplish the LANDING checklist down to flaps. State “HOLDING AT FLAPS.” | | At glide slope capture, verify proper mode annunciation, check N1 reference bug at the go–around limit and set missed approach altitude. | | | Call “FLAPS ____” as required for landing. Set MCP speed selector at VREF + 5 knots. | Position FLAP lever as directed. | | At final approach fix/OM, verify crossing altitude. | Verify crossing altitude. | | Call “COMPLETE THE LANDING CHECKLIST.” | Complete the LANDING checklist. | | Monitor approach progress and guard the controls. | | | At 500 feet AGL, verify FLARE is armed. | | | At approximately 50 feet AGL, verify FLARE is engaged. | | | Ensure the autothrottle retards the thrust levers to idle by touchdown. | |

FLAP lever to 15 and monitor flap
retraction. | | Call “FLAPS 15.” | | | If full GA thrust is required, push
TO/GA switch again after reduced
GA thrust is established. | | | Confirm rotation to go–around
attitude and monitor autopilot. | | | Verify mode annunciation. | | | When positive rate of climb is
indicated, call “GEAR UP” and
monitor acceleration. | Verify positive rate of climb.
Position landing gear lever UP. | | Check flight instrument indications
(MCP speed window blanks). | | | Call “TUNE RADIOS FOR
MISSED APPROACH.” | Tune radios as directed. | | Above 400 feet, select appropriate
roll mode and verify proper mode
annunciation. | Observe mode annunciation. | | Retract flaps on flap speed

altitude and maintains flap

**[Context Text]** Landing Roll Procedure WARNING: After reverse thrust has been initiated, a full stop landing must be made. **[Visual Analysis]** | PILOT FLYING | PILOT NOT FLYING | |---|---| | Ensure thrust levers at idle. | | | Disengage autopilot and control airplane manually. | Verify autothrottle is disengaged. | | Verify autothrottle disengages automatically. | | | Verify SPEED BRAKE lever (ground spoilers) - UP. | Verify SPEED BRAKE lever UP.
Call out “SPEED BRAKES UP.”
If SPEED BRAKE lever not UP,
call “SPEED BRAKES NOT UP.” | | Verify proper autobrake operation. | | | Without delay, raise reverse thrust levers to the interlocks, hold light pressure until release, and then apply reverse thrust as required. | Monitor engine instruments and announce any engine limit being approached, exceeded or any other abnormalities. | | At 60 knots, reduce reverse thrust to be at IDLE reverse when reaching taxi speed. | Call “60 KNOTS” | | Approaching taxi speed, slowly move the reverse thrust levers to the full down position. | Verify REV indication extinguished. | | Prior to taxi speed, disarm the autobrake and continue manual braking as required. | |

**[Context Text]**:
Takeoff

**[Visual Analysis]**:
First, during the `Thrust set` phase, manually advance thrust to stabilize, then press TO/GA.
Next, `LNAV armed` as required.
Then, `Takeoff thrust by 60 knots`.
At `V1`, a decision speed, the aircraft continues acceleration.
At `VR`, `Rotate` the aircraft for liftoff.
Upon achieving a `Positive rate of climb`, `Gear up`. If 2 engines, accelerate to `V2+15 to 25 knots`. If 1 engine, accelerate to `V2 to V2+20 knots`.
Next, at `Acceleration height flap retraction altitude (normally 1000 ft.)`:
*   Set/verify climb thrust (2 engine).
*   Select flaps up maneuvering speed.
*   Retract flaps on schedule.
At `400 feet AGL`, `Select roll mode`.
Then, at `3000 feet`:
*   One or 2 engine climb speed.
*   VNAV engaged (as installed).
Finally, when `Flaps up`:
*   Maintain flaps up maneuvering speed or select LVL CHG (1 engine).
*   Maintain flaps up maneuvering speed (2 engine).
*   Set max continuous thrust (1 engine).
*   Non-Normal checklist (if required).
*   After Takeoff checklist.

**[Context Text]**
ILS Approach

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram illustrates the procedural flow for an ILS approach, including phases from initial approach to touchdown and a missed approach procedure.

**Sequence of an ILS Approach:**

1.  **Approaching intercept heading:**
    *   Flaps 5
    *   *Alternatively, or following:*
        *   Flaps 1 (This step is shown as a transition after initial flap setting towards Localizer capture).
    *   *Concurrently, or as an alternative initial phase:*
    **On RADAR vectors:**
        *   HDG SEL
        *   Appropriate pitch mode
        *   LNAV or appropriate roll mode
        *   VNAV or appropriate pitch mode
2.  **Localizer capture:**
    *   Final approach course heading
3.  **Intercept Heading:**
    *   ILS tuned & identified
    *   LOC & G/S pointers displayed
    *   Select APP
    *   Second A/P CMD (Dual channel)
4.  **Fix (LOM, MKR, DME):**
    *   Verify crossing altitude
5.  **Glideslope intercept:**
    *   Landing flaps (2 engine)
    *   Set missed approach altitude
    *   Complete Landing checklist (2 engine)
6.  **Glideslope alive:**
    *   Gear down
    *   Flaps 15 (final flap for 1 engine)
    *   Arm speedbrake
    *   Landing checklist (to flaps for 2 engine)
7.  **500 Feet:**
    *   Check FLARE armed (Dual channel)
8.  **Minimum Single Channel Autopilot Use Altitude:**
    *   (see Limitations chapter)
    *   Disengage A/P
9.  **Touchdown:**
    *   Disengage A/P (Dual channel)

**Missed Approach Procedure:**
A missed approach can be initiated from the "Glideslope intercept," "Glideslope alive," or "Minimum Single Channel Autopilot Use Altitude" phases.
*   **Missed approach:**
    *   Push TO/GA switch
    *   Go-around thrust
    *   Go-around attitude
    *   Flaps 15 (flaps 1, 1 engine)
    *   Positive rate of climb, gear up
    *   Retract flaps on schedule
    *   After Takeoff checklist

**[Context Text]**
Instrument Approach using VNAV

**[Visual Analysis]**
The process for an Instrument Approach using VNAV begins with the aircraft receiving **On RADAR vectors**, where the crew selects HDG SEL and an appropriate pitch mode. From this point, the aircraft can proceed directly **Enroute to fix**, utilizing LNAV or an appropriate roll mode, and VNAV or an appropriate pitch mode.

Alternatively, from **On RADAR vectors**, the aircraft proceeds to **Approaching intercept heading** with Flaps 5.

**Next, at Intercept Heading**, the crew arms LNAV or an appropriate roll mode.

**Subsequently, when Inbound (1.5 NM)**, the procedure involves:
*   Gear down
*   Flaps 15 (landing flaps 1 engine)
*   Arm speedbrake
*   Set MDA/DA
*   Select VNAV
*   Speed intervention (as installed)
*   Landing flaps (2 engine)

The aircraft then reaches the **FAF (Final Approach Fix)**.

**From FAF, two main paths are possible:**

1.  **To Descend to MDA/DA**, which includes:
    *   Monitor VNAV path
    *   Set missed approach altitude in MCP
    *   Landing checklist

2.  **Upon reaching At MDA/DA**, the crew performs these actions:
    *   Intercept landing profile
    *   Disengage autopilot and autothrottle

**A Missed approach** can be initiated from either the **FAF** or **MDA/DA**. The steps for a missed approach are:
*   Push TO/GA switch
*   Flaps 15 (flaps 1, 1 engine)
*   Go-around attitude
*   Go-around thrust
*   Achieve a positive rate of climb, then retract gear up
*   Above 400 feet, select roll mode
*   At flap retraction attitude, set speed for desired flap setting
*   Retract flaps on schedule
*   After flap retraction, select LVL CHG or VNAV as required
*   Select CLB/CON thrust
*   Verify tracking route and altitude capture
*   Complete the After Takeoff checklist

**After a missed approach**, the aircraft transitions **Enroute to fix**, which requires:
*   LNAV or appropriate roll mode
*   VNAV or appropriate pitch mode.

**[Context Text]**
Instrument Approach using V/S

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram illustrates the process for an Instrument Approach using V/S, including a possible missed approach.

First, the aircraft is **Approaching intercept heading** with Flaps 5.
Then, for **Intercept Heading**, arm LNAV or appropriate roll mode.
Next, when **On RADAR vectors**, select HDG SEL and an appropriate pitch mode.
Following this, **Enroute to fix**, engage LNAV or appropriate roll mode, and VNAV or appropriate pitch mode.

When **Inbound (1.5 NM)**:
*   Gear down.
*   Flaps 15 (landing flaps 1 engine).
*   Arm speedbrake.
*   Set MDA.
*   Landing flaps (2 engine).

Proceeding to **Descend to MDA**:
*   Set V/S.
*   Complete Landing checklist.

Upon **Approaching MDA**:
*   Set missed approach altitude in MCP.

At **At MDA**:
*   Intercept landing profile and disengage autopilot and autothrottle.

If a **Missed approach** is initiated:
*   Push TO/GA switch.
*   Select Flaps 15 (flaps 1, 1 engine).
*   Establish Go-around attitude.
*   Apply Go-around thrust.
*   Ensure Positive rate of climb, gear up.
*   Above 400 feet, select roll mode.
*   At flap retraction altitude, set speed for desired flap setting.
*   Retract flaps on schedule.
*   After flap retraction, select LVL CHG or VNAV as required.
*   Select CLB/CON thrust.
*   Verify tracking route and altitude capture.
*   Perform After Takeoff checklist.

**[Context Text]**
Circling Approach

**[Visual Analysis]**
This diagram illustrates the procedures for a Circling Approach, from the turning base to intercepting the landing profile or executing a missed approach.

First, during the **Turning Base**, the aircraft's configuration requires:
*   Gear down (if operating on 1 engine)
*   Landing flaps (if not previously selected)
*   Completion of the Landing checklist

Then, at the **Configuration at MDA (Minimum Descent Altitude)**, the aircraft should have:
*   Gear down
*   Gear up (if operating on 1 engine)
*   Flaps 15
*   Flaps 10 (if operating on 1 engine)
*   Arm speedbrake

Concurrently with the Configuration at MDA, for the **MCP Altitude / MDA** settings:
*   Select ALT HOLD (if required)
*   Set the missed approach altitude
*   Select HDG SEL

Next, when **Intercepting Landing Profile**:
*   Disengage autopilot
*   Disengage autothrottle

Alternatively, if a **Missed approach** is necessary:
*   Make a climbing turn in the shortest direction toward the landing runway
*   Execute the missed approach

**[Context Text]**
Visual Traffic Pattern

**[Visual Analysis]**
First, when Entering downwind, the aircraft sets Flaps 5.

Then, Prior to turning base, the aircraft performs the following actions: Gear down, Flaps 15 (landing flaps for 1 engine), Arm speedbrake, and Start descent as required. This occurs at approximately 1500 FT.

Next, on the Base leg, the aircraft sets Landing flaps (2 engine) and completes the Landing checklist.

Following the base leg, during the final approach, the aircraft maintains 700 - 500 FT and is Stabilized on profile, approximately 2 - 2 1/2 NM from the runway.

As an alternative procedure from the approach phase, a Go-around may be initiated by:
- Pushing the TO/GA switch.
- Applying Go-around thrust.
- Establishing a Go-around attitude.
- Setting Flaps 15 (flaps 1 for 1 engine).
- Ensuring a Positive rate of climb.
- Retracting the gear up.
- Retracting flaps on schedule.
- Completing the After Takeoff checklist.

**[Context Text]**
Note: If an approach must be made into an area of severe turbulence, delay flap extension as long as possible. The airplane can withstand higher gust loads in the clean configuration.

**[Visual Analysis]**
| PHASE OF FLIGHT | AIRSPEED |
|---|---|
| CLIMB | 280 knots or .76 Mach |
| CRUISE | Use FMC recommended thrust settings. If the FMC is inoperative, refer to the Unreliable Airspeed page in the Performance—Inflight section for approximate N1 settings that maintain near optimum penetration airspeed. |
| DESCENT | .76 Mach/280/250 knots. If severe turbulence is encountered at altitudes below 15,000 feet and the airplane gross weight is less than the maximum landing weight, the airplane may be slowed to 250 knots in the clean configuration. |

**[Context Text]**
Takeoff Obstacle Limit Weight
Flaps 5
Sea Level 30°C & Below, Zero Wind
Based on engine bleed for packs on and anti-ice off

- With engine anti-ice on, decrease weight by 150 kg.
- With engine and wing anti-ice on, decrease weight by 700 kg.

**[Context Text]**
Quick Turnaround Limit Weight
Flaps 40

Increase weight by 700 kg per 1% uphill slope. Decrease weight by 950 kg per 1% downhill slope.
Increase weight by 1750 kg per 10 knots headwind. Decrease weight by 6400 kg per 10 knots tailwind.

After landing at weights exceeding those shown above, adjusted for slope and wind, wait at least 62 minutes and check that wheel thermal plugs have not melted before executing a takeoff.

As an alternate procedure, ensure that each brake pressure plate surface temperature, without artificial cool- ing, is less than 218°C as follows: No sooner than 10 and no later than 15 minutes after parking, measure each brake pressure plate surface temperature at a minimum of two points per brake by an accurate method (using a Doric Microtemp 450 hand held thermometer or equivalent, hold temperature probe in place for 20 seconds or until reading stabilizes). If each measured temperature is less than 218°C, immediate dispatch is allowed; otherwise the required minimum ground wait period of 62 minutes applies.

Miscellaneous Exterior Lights
[Option - Typical]

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram displays the FORWARD OVERHEAD PANEL, which contains the miscellaneous exterior light switches.
Step [1]: The LOGO Light Switch controls the logo lights. When OFF, logo lights on each side of the vertical fin are extinguished. When ON, logo lights are illuminated.
Step [2]: The POSITION Light Switch has three positions. In STROBE & STEADY, red and green wing-tip position lights, white trailing edge wing-tip lights, and wing-tip and tail strobe lights are illuminated. When OFF, red and green wing-tip position lights, white trailing edge wing-tip lights, and wing-tip and tail strobe lights are extinguished. In STEADY, red and green wing-tip position lights and white trailing edge wing-tip lights are illuminated.

Step [5]: The ANTI-COLLISION Light Switch controls the red rotating beacon lights on the upper and lower fuselage. When OFF, these lights are extinguished. When ON, they are illuminated.

**[Context Text]**
Flight Deck Emergency Access Panel

**[Visual Analysis]**
The Flight Deck Emergency Access Panel is located on the PASSENGER SIDE DOOR POST.

**[Context Text]**
Flight Deck Access System Switch

1 Flight Deck Access System Switch
OFF - removes electrical power from door lock.
NORM (Normal) - flight deck access system configured for flight.

Flight Deck Door Lock Panel

1 LOCK FAIL Light
Illuminated (amber) - Flight Deck Door Lock selector in AUTO and door lock has failed or Flight Deck Access System switch is OFF.

2 AUTO Unlock (UNLK) Light
Illuminated (amber) - correct emergency access code entered in keypad. AUTO UNLK light flashes and continuous chime sounds before timer expires and door unlocks.

**[Visual Analysis]**
First, the Flight Deck Access System Switch is located on the FLIGHT DECK SIDE DOOR POST. Step [1] indicates the Flight Deck Access System switch, which has two positions: OFF and NORM. When in the OFF position, it removes electrical power from the door lock. When in the NORM position, the flight deck access system is configured for flight.

Then, the Flight Deck Door Lock Panel is located on the AISLE STAND. Step [1] indicates the LOCK FAIL light. This light illuminates amber if the Flight Deck Door Lock selector is in AUTO and the door lock has failed, or if the Flight Deck Access System switch is OFF. Step [2] indicates the AUTO UNLK light. This light illuminates amber if the correct emergency access code is entered in the keypad, causing the AUTO UNLK light to flash and continuous chime sounds before a timer expires and the door unlocks. Step [3] indicates the FLT DK DOOR selector switch, which has positions for AUTO, UNLKD, and DENY.

**[Context Text]**
3 Flight Deck (FLT DK) Door Lock Selector
Spring loaded to AUTO. Selector must be pushed in to rotate from AUTO to UNLKD. Selector must not be pushed in to rotate from AUTO to DENY.
UNLKD - door unlocked while selector in UNLKD.
AUTO - door locked. Allows door to unlock after entry of emergency access code and expiration of timer, unless crew takes action.
DENY - rejects keypad entry request and prevents further emergency access code entry for a time period.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram shows the interior view of a Passenger Entry/Galley Service Door from the PASSENGER CABIN. The door features a CONTROL HANDLE at the top right, with an ASSIST HANDLE positioned below it. An INSTRUCTION PLACARD is located centrally on the door panel, above the SLIDE COMPARTMENT. To the right of the instruction placard is a SLIDE PRESSURE GAUGE VIEWER. STOWAGE HOOKS are located on the right side of the slide compartment. The SLIDE COMPARTMENT occupies the lower central area of the door, with the GIRT located at its bottom edge. At the very bottom of the door structure are FLOOR BRACKETS and a GIRT BAR.

The Oxygen Panel is located on the AFT OVERHEAD PANEL and includes the following components:
Step [1]: The Flight CREW OXYGEN Pressure Indicator is a circular gauge labeled "CREW OXYGEN" and "OXY PRESS PS1 X 100". This indicator shows the pressure at the crew oxygen cylinder.
Step [2]: The Passenger Oxygen (PASS OXYGEN) Switch is a two-position switch labeled "NORMAL" and "ON". The NORMAL position is guarded. In the NORMAL (guarded) position, passenger masks drop and the passenger oxygen system activates automatically if cabin altitude climbs to 14,000 feet.
Step [3]: The "PASS OXY ON" light illuminates to indicate that the passenger oxygen system is active.

**[Context Text]**
ON – activates system and drops masks if automatic function fails.
3 Passenger Oxygen On Light
Illuminated (amber) – passenger oxygen system is operating and masks have dropped.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram depicts the Oxygen Mask Panel located at the CREWMEMBER STATION.
First, [1] the Oxygen Flow Indicator is a circular display at the top left of the panel that indicates a yellow cross when oxygen is flowing.
Next, [2] the RESET/TEST Slide Lever is positioned on the left side of the oxygen mask stowage. Pushing this lever activates oxygen flow momentarily to test the regulator if the mask is stowed. If the mask is not stowed and the stowage box doors are closed, pushing this lever retracts the OXY ON flag, shuts off oxygen, and shuts off the microphone.
Finally, [3] the Inflation Levers are located near the oxygen mask on the right side of the panel. Squeezing and pulling up these levers releases the mask from its stowage box and releases the OXY ON flag when the stowage box doors open.

**[Context Text]**
*   activates oxygen and microphone

*   flow indicator shows a yellow cross momentarily as harness inflates.
**Oxygen Mask and Regulator**

**[Visual Analysis]**
The image depicts an Oxygen Mask and Regulator at a CREWMEMBER STATION. The main components shown are the HARNESS (shown inflated), MASK, MICROPHONE, and REGULATOR.

Step [1]: The NORMAL/100% Switch. In the 'N (normal)' position, it supplies an air/oxygen mixture on demand, where the ratio depends on cabin altitude. In the '100%' position, it supplies 100% oxygen on demand.
Step [2]: The Oxygen Mask EMERGENCY/Test Selector (rotary). When rotated to 'EMERGENCY', it supplies 100% oxygen under positive pressure at all cabin altitudes. The 'PRESS TO TEST' function tests the positive pressure supply to the regulator.
Step [3]: The Smoke Vent Valve Selector. When positioned 'Up', the vent valve is closed. When positioned 'Down', the vent valve is open, allowing oxygen flow to smoke goggles.

**[Context Text]**
Forward Airstairs
Interior and Exterior Controls
[Option]

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram illustrates the controls for the Forward Airstairs, distributed across two primary locations: the **FORWARD ATTENDANT PANEL** and a panel located **BELOW AND AFT OF FWD ENTRY DOOR**.

First, at the **FORWARD ATTENDANT PANEL**:
- **[1] LIGHTS Switch:** This switch controls the illumination of the airstair tread lights. In the AUTO position, the lights illuminate automatically upon airstair extension and extinguish upon retraction. In the ON position, the airstair tread lights are continuously illuminated.
- **[2] Normal Control Switches (RETRACT/EXTEND):** These switches are used for the normal operation of the airstair. AC and DC electrical power must be available on the airplane for their use. Selecting RETRACT retracts the airstair, requiring the handrail extensions to be stowed first. Selecting EXTEND extends the airstair.
- **[3] STANDBY Control Switch:** This switch provides a standby method for airstair operation. To use it, the switch must be held in either the EXTEND or RETRACT position, and the Battery switch must be ON. Selecting EXTEND extends the airstair, and selecting RETRACT retracts the airstair. A CAUTION notes that using standby bypasses all safety circuits, and airstair handrail extensions must be stowed to prevent substantial damage.
- **[4] STAIRS Operating (OPER) Light:** This amber light illuminates when the airstair is in transit (either extending or retracting).

Then, at the panel **BELOW AND AFT OF FWD ENTRY DOOR**:
- **[5] Panel:** This panel, labeled "BELOW AND AFT OF FWD ENTRY DOOR," houses additional controls for the airstair system.
- **[2] AIRSTAIRS RETRACT/EXTEND Switch:** A second set of Normal Control Switches for airstair retraction and extension is located on this panel.
- **[6] POWER STANDBY NEUTRAL Switch:** A control switch labeled "POWER STANDBY NEUTRAL" is located on this panel.

Water System Controls

**[Visual Analysis]**

**[Context Text]**
[Option: Winglets]
Flight Deck Lighting
Flight deck lighting is provided for panel illumination, area lighting and localized illumination. Dome lights supply general flight deck flood lighting. The glareshield supplies background light for the main instrument panels. Each instrument and instrument panel has its own integral lights. Floodlights are installed for the MCP, aisle stand, and aft circuit breaker panel.
Map lights, chart lights and utility lights are available at the pilot stations, each with individual controls.
If normal electrical power is lost, standby electrical power is automatically provided to the standby compass light, dome lights, instrument flood lights and selected system information and warning lights.
Passenger Cabin Lighting
Passenger cabin lighting is supplied by incandescent and fluorescent lights. General cabin lighting is provided by window lights, ceiling lights, and entry lights. Reading lights are located above each passenger seat in the passenger service unit. Lights are also installed in the lavatories and galleys.

Oxygen Systems
Two independent oxygen systems are provided, one for the flight crew and one for the passengers. Portable oxygen cylinders can be located throughout the airplane for emergency use. These cylinders are normally found in the forward and aft areas of the passenger cabin.

**[Context Text]**
Oxygen System Schematic

**[Visual Analysis]**
The Oxygen System Schematic illustrates the distribution of oxygen within the aircraft. A Crew Oxygen Cylinder supplies high-pressure oxygen. This high-pressure oxygen flows through a Pressure Reducer. From the Pressure Reducer, oxygen is supplied to the Oxygen Mask (Typical) for crew use. The Crew Oxygen Cylinder also has a Thermal Discharge Port.

Crew oxygen pressure is monitored by a Crew Oxygen indicator, which displays OXY PRESS PSI x 100. A PASS OXYGEN switch/light indicates NORMAL operation when in the ON position.

The system includes a 14,000 FT BAROMETRIC PRESSURE SWITCH, which activates the passenger oxygen system. From this switch, low-pressure oxygen is distributed to Passenger Service Units and Attendant Stations, including Lavatories.

Passenger Service Units typically contain 4 masks and include a Chemical Oxygen Generator (O2G). Attendant Stations and Lavatories typically contain 2 masks and also include a Chemical Oxygen Generator (O2G) in each service unit.

The legend indicates that a solid line represents HIGH PRESSURE and a dashed line represents LOW PRESSURE. The condition shown in the schematic is NORMAL.

**[Context Text]**
Portable Protective Breathing Equipment
Protective Breathing Equipment (PBE/Smoke Hood) devices for crew use (for combating fires and/or entering areas of smoke or fume accumulation) may be stowed throughout the airplane; however, they are normally found in the forward and aft sections of the passenger cabin. The device is placed over the head and, when activated, provides approximately 15 to over 20 minutes of oxygen depending upon the device used. Manufacturer's operating instructions are placarded on the container.

Passenger Oxygen System
The passenger oxygen system is supplied by individual chemical oxygen generators located at each Passenger Service Unit (PSU). Four continuous flow masks are connected to each generator. A generator with two masks is located above each attendant station and in each lavatory.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The "Mask Donning" diagram illustrates the procedure for wearing a Protective Breathing Equipment (PBE) or Smoke Hood.
First, a hand removes the PBE/Smoke Hood from its container.
Then, a person holds the PBE/Smoke Hood, orienting it for donning.
Next, the person places the PBE/Smoke Hood over their head, covering their face with the visor.
Finally, the person adjusts the PBE/Smoke Hood to ensure a proper and secure fit.

**[Context Text]**
The system is activated automatically by a pressure switch at a cabin altitude of 14,000 feet or when the Passenger Oxygen Switch on the aft overhead panel is positioned to ON. When the system is activated, the PASS OXY ON light illuminates and OVERHEAD illuminates on the Master Caution System.

Activating the system causes the masks to drop from the stowage compartments. The oxygen generators are activated when any mask in the unit is pulled down. Pulling one mask down causes all masks in that unit to come down and 100% oxygen flows to all masks. A green in-line flow indicator is visible in the transparent oxygen hose whenever oxygen is flowing to the mask. Oxygen flows for approximately 12 minutes and cannot be shut off. If the passenger oxygen is activated and a PSU oxygen mask compartment does not open, the masks may be dropped manually.

WARNING: When using passenger oxygen, the “NO SMOKING” sign should be strictly observed. Once the generator is activated, the flow of oxygen is constant, whether or not the mask is being worn.

WARNING: Do not use passenger oxygen with cabin altitude below 14,000 feet when smoke or an abnormal heat source is present. The use of passenger oxygen does not prevent the passengers from inhaling smoke. Air inhaled is a mixture of oxygen and cabin air.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The PSU Oxygen Mask Compartment contains a CHEMICAL OXYGEN GENERATOR located within the PSU. A RELEASE FIRING PIN is connected to the CHEMICAL OXYGEN GENERATOR. A GENERATOR LANYARD connects to the RELEASE FIRING PIN. An OXYGEN MASK LANYARD connects to the GENERATOR LANYARD, which extends to the MASK assembly. The PSU also includes a DOOR LATCH MECHANISM for the OXYGEN MASK DOOR. The OXYGEN MASK DOOR is shown in the open position, allowing the mask to deploy. An OXYGEN HOSE extends from the chemical oxygen generator, routing through an OXYGEN IN-LINE FLOW INDICATOR, and connects to a RESERVOIR BAG, which is then attached to the MASK. The diagram includes a FWD arrow indicating the forward direction relative to the PSU.

**[Context Text]**
Passenger Portable Oxygen
First aid and supplemental portable oxygen cylinders are installed at suitable locations in the passenger cabin. The cylinders are fitted with a pressure gage, pressure regulator and an on-off valve. The cylinders are pressurized to 1800 psi. At this pressure and a temperature of 70 degrees Fahrenheit (21 degrees Celsius) the cylinders have a capacity of 4.25 cubic feet (120 liters) of free oxygen. Two continuous flow outlets are provided on each cylinder, one regulates flow at two liters per minute for walk-around; the second outlet provides flow at four liters per minute. The four-liter flow is used for first aid.

Duration can be determined by dividing capacity by outflow (120 liters divided by 4 liters/minute = 30 minutes).

**[Visual Analysis]**
The Passenger Portable Oxygen Schematic illustrates the components of the system.
The system consists of an OXYGEN CYLINDER.
Attached to the top of the OXYGEN CYLINDER are an ON-OFF VALVE, a PRESSURE REGULATOR, and a PRESSURE GAUGE.
A PLACARD is located on the side of the OXYGEN CYLINDER.
The oxygen cylinder supplies two CONSTANT FLOW OUTLETS: one providing a 4 LITER FLOW and another providing a 2 LITER FLOW.
The schematic shows a user receiving oxygen via a mask connected to one of the constant flow outlets.

**[Context Text]**
Fire Extinguishers are located in the flight deck and passenger cabin.
Water fire extinguishers contain a solution of water mixed with antifreeze. The container is pressurized by a CO2 cartridge when the extinguisher handle is rotated fully clockwise. The extinguisher should be used on fabric, paper or wood fires only.
To use the water fire extinguisher:
* remove from stowage
* rotate handle fully clockwise
* aim at base of fire and press trigger.
CAUTION: Do not use on electrical or grease type fires.
Halon (BCF) fire extinguishers contain a liquefied gas agent under pressure. The pressure indicator shows an acceptable pressure range, a recharge range, and an overcharged range. A safety pin with a pull ring prevents accidental trigger movement. When released the liquefied gas agent vaporizes and extinguishes the fire. The extinguisher is effective on all types of fires, but primarily on electrical, fuel and grease fires.

**[Visual Analysis]**
The Water Fire Extinguisher consists of a main container with a handle located at the top. The handle assembly includes a TRIGGER SAFETY WIRED component, which is connected to a DISCHARGE NOZZLE through which the extinguishing agent is expelled.

**[Context Text]**
To use the Halon fire extinguisher:
*   remove from stowage
*   hold upright and remove ringed safety pin
*   aim at base of fire from a distance of six feet and press top lever
*   use side to side motion to suppress fire.
BCF Fire Extinguisher (Halon 1211)

**[Visual Analysis]**
The diagram identifies the components of a BCF Fire Extinguisher (Halon 1211). The DISCHARGE NOZZLE is located at the front, top of the extinguisher body. The LEVER is positioned above the handle mechanism. The RING SAFETY PIN is inserted through the lever to prevent accidental discharge. A PRESSURE GAUGE is visible on the side of the valve assembly, indicating the extinguisher's charge. The HANDLE is located on the opposite side of the discharge nozzle, below the lever, for carrying and operating the extinguisher. The main body of the cylinder is labeled as containing HALON.
